title: The one change to Zed that could make him legitimately balanced.
body:
Lower the AD ratio on his E significantly. His E is not meant to blow up entire teams, it's used to slow targets to land shurikens. Sure, it does damage to help in combos, but it's just plain stupid when a Zed who can't aim to save their lives uses the fabled W-E combo and takes off half your HP, just because you were unlucky enough to be in range.

Shift the damage from his E elsewhere. We're all tired of taking 600+ damage (give or take) from a slow.

PS: This is just an idea. Put down your pitchforks, people.

EDIT: To those people who are hinged on the numbers I'm providing, it's an rough estimate. Some days I've had Zed deal 700, others he deals 100. Regardless, instead of arguing semantics and exacts, don't forget that this isn't a place for pushing your beliefs onto others or trying to defend Zed, or attack him. Guy's got bigger things to worry about than everyone fighting over him.

A thoughtful player named iDarkWind came up with a possible change to the ability itself with a pretty cool mechanic.
> SHADOW SLASH: Zed spins his blades, dealing 40 / 60 / 80 / 100 / 120 (+45% Bonus AD) physical damage to nearby enemies and reducing Living Shadow's cooldown by 2 seconds for every enemy champion hit. Enemies struck are MARKED for 4 seconds.

Zed's Q and Zed's Auto-Attacks proc the MARK, dealing 30 / 40 / 50 / 60 / 70 (+45% Bonus AD) physical damage.

Numbers here are debatable, but the idea still stands. What do you guys think?

Mathematically, when you multiply by a percentage (in this case, an increase of 25% bonus AD), you're actually multiplying by 1.25, not 0.25. Multiplying by 0.25 would result in a 75% decrease of bonus AD. The wiki says a 25% increase, but in actuality they're taking the bonus AD value and multiplying by 1.25, or 125%.

Now, you'd be correct if he said 125% _increase_, in which case that would be multiplying by 2.25, or 225%.

It's a common mistake though, so I'm not trying to be rude about it.
It's not multiplicative though, it's additive, adding 25% bonus ad, that's the way it's worded, as if it's adding that 25%

Same thing as multiplying bonus AD by 1.25

It's an equivalent statement. Think of it like "Multiply by 1 and a quarter, so add a quarter"

Well, the game multiplies by 1.25 to make it quicker. If it were additive, you'd first have to take your bonus AD, multiply by 0.25 (or divide by 4) and then add the quotient of that to your bonus AD value.

Or the game could just take the bonus AD and multiply by 1.25 and be done with it. I know it shaves off only 1-2 steps, but when optimizing a game, you want to cut down on any inefficient code as much as humanly possible.

From a Mathematical view, you're not wrong. You're going to get the same answer, regardless of however many steps you make (unless you start making the wrong steps...).
